proof: Proof. The function $x \to xe^{-x}$ is (strictly) decreasing on $x \in (1, \infty)$ and (strictly) increasing on $x \in (0, 1)$, thus there is a unique conjugate for each $d > 1$ in $(0, 1)$ and in particular, note that if for $a \in (0, 1)$ it holds that $ae^{-a} > de^{-d}$, then $\mu(d) < a$. We can easily verify that $e^{-d/2}e^{-e^{-d/2}} > de^{-d}$ holds for all $d \ge 3$.
